title: Only In Lebanon Are Anti-Government Protests A Giant Singing & Dancing Street Party!
text:
These videos and pictures look nothing but a scene of giant celebrations on the streets. However, a closer look would reveal it all.

Thousands of people in Lebanon thronged public spaces in capital Beirut and across Lebanon on October 20 in the largest protests in the country since 2005. The protests proved to be a great unifier for an often divided public in revolt against traditional leaders who have ruled for three decades and brought the economy to the brink of disaster.

The uprising began four days ago after the government announced new tax proposals.

However, the protests were not anything like a regular protest scene.

Rallies turned into parties with music blaring and protesters dancing, singing and chanting, “The people want to bring down the regime.”

People were seen carrying placards that read, “Happiest depressed people you’ll ever meet.”

"'Happiest depressed people you'll ever meet': Lebanon protests erupt for fourth day" https://t.co/dCom5MTG5n — Dawndawn (@Dawndaw41131715) October 21, 2019

I love that Lebanese from all over the world are protesting in solidarity. The Lebanese diaspora is strength! To be Lebanese is an out of country experience. There are more Lebanese out side of Lebanon — Z-MUNNIE™ (@zbaalbaki) October 21, 2019

In mornings, men and women carried blue bags and cleaned the streets of the capital, Beirut, picking up trash left behind by the previous night’s protests.

In Beirut, small bathing pools were set up on the main ring-road and in Martyr's Square, men reclining in them shirtless.

Shisha pipes have been pervasive, with sidewalks transformed into impromptu cafes.

Lebanon suffers from high unemployment, little growth and one of the highest debts ratios in the world, standing at 150 per cent of the gross domestic product. Public services have remained off for years now and power stations remain dilapidated.

The proposed new taxes that sparked the protests were part of stringent austerity measures aimed at tackling crisis, measures that critics say fall mainly on the struggling public.
